subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] International Quikscript
msgSnippet: Is English an unusual language in this regard? I suppose ESL students must be taught the subtle differences in emphasis in speech such as: 1) What do YOU
messageBody:
Is English an unusual language in this regard? I suppose ESL students
must be taught the subtle differences in emphasis in speech such as:
1) What do YOU think?
2) Wuh-duh-yuh think?
3) D'yuh THINK?

I can't remember any such instruction (ignoring elision in French) in
my foreign language classes. Was I simply not advanced enough for
this?

Ted


On Mon, Sep 1, 2008 at 12:19 PM, John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:
<snip>

> Indeed. There are many short English words that have both strong and
> weak pronunciations. For example, the words "him" and "her" have weak
> pronunciations without the "h" (this has nothing to do with h-dropping in
> certain accents; it is a universal feature of up-to-speed English speech).
> In the same way, the strong form of "you" has Ooze, whereas the weak form
> has Utter. No proposed orthography that I know of represents the weak
> form of any word other than "the", and why should it be an exception to
> the strong-only rule?
>
> --
> John Cowan <cowan@...> http://www.ccil.org/~cowan
> Charles li reis, nostre emperesdre magnes,
> Set anz totz pleinz ad ested in Espagnes.
>
>
